title: Look inside Back Bay’s Sheraton Boston after a $100 million renovation
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Sheraton Boston in Back Bay completes a $100 million renovation for its 60th anniversary, updating lobby, guest rooms, and dining areas.
The renovation introduces redesigned guest rooms with views, sit-stand desks, ambient lighting, and enhances meeting spaces with The Studio collection.
New amenities include a 24-hour fitness studio, Boston's largest hotel lap pool, private cabanas, a restaurant, and The Sheraton Club lounge for Marriott members.

title: Insider predicts how Alex Bregman, Trevor Story will handle player options with Red Sox this offseason
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Alex Bregman is likely to opt out of his contract with the Red Sox this offseason for potentially longer lucrative deals.
Trevor Story is expected to opt in and stay with the Red Sox for the last two years of his contract.
If Bregman leaves, Marcelo Mayer is likely to fill third base; Story staying ensures shortstop stability for 2026.

title: Roman Anthony played a big role getting the Red Sox into playoff position. It’s on the veterans to play into October.
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Roman Anthony suffers a left oblique strain, likely sidelined 4-6 weeks, impacting Red Sox playoff push.
Red Sox are 3.5 games behind Blue Jays in AL East, with a 98.1% postseason chance.
Veterans like Trevor Story and Masataka Yoshida key in maintaining momentum as Anthony recovers.

title: Review: ‘The Paper’ shows promise, even as ‘The Office’ legacy looms large
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: "The Paper" is a spinoff of NBC's "The Office," streaming its first season on Peacock.
Oscar Nuñez reprises his role as Oscar Martinez, and the show features Domhnall Gleeson as new editor-in-chief Ned.
Co-creator Greg Daniels aims to replicate previous successes with "The Paper" renewed for a second season.

title: Randy Moss opened up about cancer battle, support he received, and helping Deion Sanders
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Randy Moss, ex-ESPN analyst and NFL player, revealed he was diagnosed with Stage 2 bile-duct cancer in 2024.
Moss underwent a complex six-hour surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation, leading to remission and his TV return.
Moss reflected on his brother’s death and supported Deion Sanders, who also faced a cancer battle.

title: 2 young adults killed in midday N.H. crash
author: John Waller
bullets: A 25-year-old woman and an 18-year-old man were killed in a three-vehicle crash at 1 p.m. in Barrington, N.H.
The crash involved two passenger vehicles and a commercial vehicle at Route 125 and Newtown Plains Road.
An 83-year-old woman was injured and hospitalized; the crash is under investigation by local police.

title: Woman who ran over pedestrian at South Bay Mall had 15 used needles in handbag, authorities say
author: John Waller
bullets: Ariella Bezan, 25, charged with operating under the influence after hitting woman in South Bay Mall lot.
Officers found 15 used needles and drug paraphernalia in Bezan's vehicle after the incident.
Bezan claimed her autistic sister grabbed the wheel; bail set at $1,500, court date on September 24.

title: Should we hope that Mike Vrabel’s debut as Patriots coach goes as well as Jerod Mayo’s did? Actually, yes.
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Mike Vrabel begins his debut season as Patriots coach against the Raiders at Gillette Stadium on Sunday.
Jerod Mayo's Patriots coaching tenure started with a 16-10 victory over the Bengals but ended after just one season.
Raiders rookie running back Ashton Jeanty, a high draft pick, could challenge the Patriots' defense in the season opener.

title: A Mass. historical home tour just ranked the best in the U.S.
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: The House of the Seven Gables in Salem, MA, was ranked the best historical home tour in the U.S. by Newsweek.
Built in 1668, the Turner-Ingersoll Mansion inspired Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel and is a National Historic Landmark.
The tour addresses various historical narratives, including stories of women, indentured laborers, and Indigenous peoples.

title: 10 burning questions about the 2025 Patriots ahead of their season opener
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The Patriots open the 2025 season under new coach Mike Vrabel with an overhauled roster, including Drake Maye and Stefon Diggs.
Key injuries and changes include Christian Gonzalez's hamstring issue and surprising roster cuts like Jabrill Peppers.
Rookie contributions and veteran performances, including those from Will Campbell, TreVeyon Henderson, and K'Lavon Chaisson, are under scrutiny.
